reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s multiplicative “product of factors” model (Sec. 2.4) and related framing, arguing it builds fragility in by choice of aggregator. That point is relevant and would weaken one important intuitive plank of the case for ‘no easy eutopia,’ but it is not fully central because the paper also argues for fussiness via multiple other routes (historical moral catastrophe examples; the more technical bounded/unbounded, linearity, goods/bads aggregation analysis in Sec. 3). Strength is limited because the paper presents multiplicativity as a toy/one model rather than a proved necessity, and much of the later argument for fussiness does not depend on strict multiplicativity. Still, the critique correctly notes that multiplicativity is not a neutral default and that alternative aggregators could be more compensatory, which would blunt the inference from “many dimensions” to “near-best outcomes are rare.” The critique is clear, focused, and has little fluff; its main overreach is implying the product model is the ‘core’ or sole engine rather than a suggestive illustration among several arguments.
title: The multiplicative moral factors model assumes fragility
